problem_statement: Find the volume of a parallelepiped determined by three vectors \( \mathbf{u}, \mathbf{v}, \mathbf{w} \) using the triple scalar product.

steps.explanation: The triple scalar product \( \mathbf{u} \cdot (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{w}) \) gives the volume of the parallelepiped formed by the vectors \( \mathbf{u}, \mathbf{v}, \mathbf{w} \). It is computed using the determinant of a 3×3 matrix formed by these vectors as rows.
expressions: $\mathbf{u} \cdot (\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{w}) = \begin{vmatrix} u_1 & u_2 & u_3 \\ v_1 & v_2 & v_3 \\ w_1 & w_2 & w_3 \end{vmatrix}$

steps.explanation: The triple scalar product is invariant under cyclic permutation. That is, the expression remains the same up to sign when vectors are rotated in order.
The volume of the parallelepiped is given by the absolute value of the triple scalar product.
In the geometric proof, the magnitude of the cross product \( \|\mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{w}\| \) represents the area of the base parallelogram.
The height of the parallelepiped is the projection of \( \mathbf{u} \) onto the normal vector \( \mathbf{v} \times \mathbf{w} \).
So the volume is height × base area, combining previous steps into a single expression.
